node.text:
In 2019, eight year old Otto Erlandsen set a goal to hike every summit in Acadia National Park. This past fall, Otto completed his goal, successfully summiting each of the 26 peaks in the park. To congratulate him, park staff passed our hats to him and shared our favorite mountains around the park. Please enjoy this light hearted video in celebration and join us in congratulating Otto by sharing your favorite mountain in the park too! 

View the video at the park website (hyperlinked) for closed captioning and audio description. 

https://www.nps.gov/acad/learn/photosmultimedia/otto-s-hat-pass.htm

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park in Acadia National Park. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
Loon Watch Friday August 13, 2021 

As the Loon Turns: Chapter 4 

I hoped to not see a loon on the nest today, since that would most likely mean that the eggs had hatched. However, there was a loon on the nest when I arrived. I did not know if that loon was the male or female. At approximately 9:15, I saw a loon swimming south. 5 minutes later, I saw 2 loons swimming together. At first, I worried that this might be an intruding loon but then realized that the nesting loon had left the floating hotel to swim with the other loon. After about 10 minutes of swimming and preening together, one swam to the nest. When it climbed onto the platform, I saw the leg bands and confirmed it was the resident female loon. She took a few minutes to rearrange the nest, did a few foot waggles and settled. The male loon continued to swim and preen for about 30 minutes, after which he swam to the floating hotel and replaced the female loon on the nest. The female loon swam away to the north. 

We anticipate that the eggs should hatch within the next few days! I am most looking forward to seeing a baby loon piggyback riding on Mom and Dad Loon. 

Loon Notes: Loon chicks can swim within a few hours of hatching. Still, they often ride piggyback on their parent. This helps keep the chick warm and safe from predators like eagles and snapping turtles. Once a baby loon reaches 4 weeks old it is usually too big for piggyback rides. A baby loon’s growth is like an infant becoming a third grader in just 4 weeks. 

Loon Fun Fact: A group of loons is called an asylum!

Photo Credit: Ray Yeager
Image: A black and white bird with a brown chick on its back swims toward the camera.

#loonwatch #acadianationalpark #loons #birdwatching #birding #nationalparks

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 15, 2021. May be art of tree and nature.

node.text: Anusha Kamat, a visitor from Malden, MA, shares a watercolor of the Ocean Path on a cloudy afternoon on July 3. "My husband and I absolutely love the outdoors and like to hike and spend time at national parks. During our travels, slowing down and capturing these moments on paper allows me to connect with these places at a deeper level and brings solace." (Photo courtesy of Anusha Kamat @colourforsoul. Used with permission.) Apply through Sept 30 for Artist-in-Residence opportunities at Acadia in 2022. More at go.nps.gov/AcadiaArt

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'NATIONAL PARK SERVICE Acadia News'.

node.text: There was a spike in emergency medical and rescue incidents across Acadia in recent days, including two Life Flight helicopter missions. Responding partners included Bar Harbor Ambulance, Bar Harbor Fire Department, Maine Forest Service, Mount Desert Island Search and Rescue, Maine Life Flight, and Friends of Acadia. More at go.nps.gov/AcadiaNews

node.text:
Stay cool in Acadia! 
 
🔥The National Weather Service has issued heat and air quality advisories in our area. 🔥
Expect hot and very humid weather reaching as high as 95 - 100° F (35 - 38° C). The air quality has been determined to be unhealthy for sensitive groups, including those with asthma or respiratory conditions. These conditions may continue through the weekend, so plan ahead to stay cool, hydrated, and healthy! 
 
— 🧘🏾‍♀️ Avoid strenuous outdoor activities, especially if you or your group have respiratory concerns. 
— 💧 Stay hydrated: drink water often and plan to bring extra. 
— 🚴🏼‍♂️ Bike or hike early in the morning or in the late afternoon to avoid midday heat.
— 🧢 Wear sunscreen, sunglasses, and a hat to protect yourself from the sun.
— 🥨 Bring salty snack to replenish salt lost from sweating. 
— 🏖 Find shady spots to take breaks.
—🤒 Familiarize yourself with signs of heat illness.

Photo Credit: Ashley L. Conti/Friends of Acadia/NPS
Image: The sun shines behind a hiker, both partially reflected by a water puddle on the trail.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people standing and outdoors.

node.text: Arun, a visitor from Collegeville, PA, shares a photo that his wife Binnie took of him with their daugher Hannah along the Wonderland Trail on July 28. "This is the first national park that Hannah is visiting. We wanted her to explore the outdoors and see how precious the national parks are. She is acting like a Super Girl trying to fly away and save the world." (Photo courtesy of Arun @_wehavebeenthere_ Used with permission.) More at http://go.nps.gov/YourAcadiaNPS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 08, 2021. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
Loon Watch 2021: As the Loon Turns 

Chapter 3 - Friday, August 6 

I arrived at Echo Lake Beach and saw one of the loons on the nest. I did not see another loon anywhere nearby. After an hour I noticed a loon swimming towards the floating loon hotel. The loon on the nest did not show any kind of agitation, indicating that the newcomer was the mate of the loon on the nest. The swimming loon paddled up to the nest where it appeared to wait to see if the nesting loon was ready for a break. The loon on the nest made no movement to leave the nest, so the other loon slowly left towards the north. A third loon, though, was now heading south towards the nest. Quickly, the swimming loon chased the intruder away. With the third loon safely gone, the loon on the hotel spent 5 minutes or so adjusting the nesting material before finally settling. The good news is that we confirmed 2 eggs are in the nest and there could be loon chicks any day. 

Loon notes: 

 Loons do not mate for life, but often have several different mates in their long lifetimes. A loon pair will usually stay together if they successfully raise chicks. If their chicks do not survive, one of the pair is displaced (as almost happened to the South Echo Lake female loon), or one of the loons dies, the other loon will find another mate. They may also move to a new nesting territory. The Somes Pond male loon has been nesting here for 19 years and has had many different mates. We think he is in his mid-twenties, since he was banded as an adult and it usually takes an adult loon 7 years or longer to establish a nesting territory. It’s possible this year’s Somes Pond loon pair will “break-up” due to the loss of their chicks. We will have to wait until next year to see if they both return to Somes Pond.

Image Credit: Nathaniel X. Boechat/Friends of Acadia
Image: A loon swims in rippling water.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 08, 2021. May be an image of twilight, sky and nature.

node.text: Joshua James Campbell, of Concord, NH, shares a photo taken at 4:45 am June 8 above Sand Beach along the Park Loop Road. "With or without coffee, mornings are not my jam. Once I'm there, though, it's worth all the suffering. This post is for all those early birds. I see you and respect you." (Photo courtesy Joshua James Campbell @paperthinhymn. Used with permission.) More at http://go.nps.gov/YourAcadiaNPS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 05, 2021. May be an image of crustacean and nature.

node.text:
Virtual Program: Tide Pool Tales
Saturday, August 7th 
4pm

Tidepooling is a popular activity in Acadia National Park.  Each tide pool is a miniature window to the ocean where many amazing plants and animals can be found. Join us as we learn how to safely explore Acadia’s intertidal habitat and the diversity found within. 

TO REGISTER: Email acaddistancelearning@schoodicinstitute.org 
Please include the name of the program and the date in the subject line (Tide Pool Tales). Register at least 2 hours before the start of the program to receive a link and a confirmation email. 

#AcadiaEducates #FindYourVirtualPark
NPS Photo/ Crystal Lewis

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 04, 2021. May be a closeup of nature.

node.text: Kelly Zehnder, of Roselle, IL, shares a photo of a Calico pennant dragonfly (Celithemis elisa) near Otter Cove on June 16. (Photo courtesy Kelly Zehnder @wildlifebykelly. Used with permission.) More at http://go.nps.gov/YourAcadiaNPS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Acadia National Park on August 04, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
Ranger Noel ventured from Acadia's Islesford Historical Museum on Little Cranberry Island to help out our neighbors at Islesford Boatworks. This community-based non-profit organization teaches boatbuilding skills to children, teens and adults. Islesford Boatworks leases the park's historic Blue Duck Ships building as their home base for preserving local maritime legacy and tradition. 
In island communities, many hands make light work; together they lifted and launched a handcrafted St. Ayles skiff into the water.

Photo credit: Allison Yanover, Steve Richard, Noel Bond/NPS
Photo 1: A large yellow wooden canoe lays on a grassy lawn in front of a brick building.
Photo 2: Four people, including one park ranger, carry a large yellow wooden canoe from a lawn into a street.
Photo 3: Four people, including one park ranger, push a large wooden canoe into water from a concrete boat launch while one person stands in the canoe with an oar.

location.name: Islesford Historical Museum and Blue Duck Ships Store

node.text:
As the Loon Turns – Chapter 2
Friday, July 30 

I arrived at Echo Lake at 8:50 am to see one adult loon, I believe to be last year’s female due to yellow and white bands on her leg, swimming near the floating loon hotel (FLH) or artificial nesting platform (ANP), (I will discuss the FLH/ANP later), and another adult loon on the nest. At 8:55 am the loons switched places. The loon getting on the nest turned the egg and settled, while the other loon swam a few hundred feet away and began preening. All was peaceful and serene for about an hour, when I noticed a third loon swimming near the preening loon. The loon on the nest hopped off the nest and began swimming rapidly towards the third loon. The third loon immediately began its takeoff towards the north, running on the water and rowing its wings. It was soon lost in the mist. The resident pair of loons swam together for a few minutes, and then last year’s female returned to the nest, turned the egg and settled. Everything remained peaceful while I was there. We should be seeing a loon chick in about 2 weeks all things being equal.

A sad note – the Somes Pond chick was attacked and injured by a juvenile bald eagle. It was rescued and taken to be evaluated. Unfortunately, its wounds were deemed too severe and it was put to rest.

Artificial Nesting Platform/Floating Loon Hotel (ANP/FLH) What are they?
- An ANP/FLH are man-made platforms made from cedar logs, PVC pipe and/or other materials. They often have turkey mesh wire used as a shade structure. A generous supply of nesting materials i.e. reeds, grasses, sedge, mud is included to help the loons nest.

Why are ANP/FLH important? The Artificial Nesting Platform, is an important management tool in certain situations:
- Where loons nested in the past, but nests failed due to nest predation i.e. eagles, mink, raccoons
- Where natural or man-made water level fluctuations caused nests to fail - rising water levels have washed eggs out of a nest, or water levels falling that have left a nest too high for the loons to gain access.
- Where nesting habitat was eliminated by shoreline development, i.e. boat docks, campgrounds, cabins, and human disturbance.

node.text: Andrew G. Petlock, of Northborough, MA, shares a portrait of a Common merganser and her chicks at Jordan Pond on May 28. "I was pleasantly surprised by how cooperative the mother was, as mergansers are typically extremely shy birds." (Photo courtesy of Andrew G. Petlock @petlock_photography. Used with permission.) More at http://go.nps.gov/YourAcadiaNPS
